data.text: @NoahMallin @tomfgoodwin @brianduroche At least they represent a significant majority of disposable income, so why not?
@tomfgoodwin Decades ago, was the industry really practising a data-driven scientific method, or relying on general heuristics? https://t.co/CEkocZ8Qy4
@tomfgoodwin @brianduroche If those are your “regular people” sure
@CraigBishop86 You have destroyed my point with this anecdote.

@tomfgoodwin Tom:  I’d suggest in “olden times” there were outfits like media buyers, offering their “expert” view of data. Now, as apparently companies (should) have a lot more of their own data, they they can do it internally.  Or think they can anyway.

@NoahMallin @tomfgoodwin Agreed, relying on any one channel alone is a bad strategy. By regular people I mean non-elite, non-marketing professionals particularly. And those people are watching as much TV as ever, 40 hours a weeks worth.

@brianduroche @tomfgoodwin I'm not sure who we are defining as "regular people" but I'm not suggesting that no-one watches ad supported TV. Just that it's not ALL they watch and the figures show a steady decline in viewership. Relying on a 15 sec spot alone to carry a message is a bad strategy.
@NoahMallin @tomfgoodwin Most regular people still watch ad supported TV--and a lot of it. and more of that than being on social media or their phones. Those are the current facts.

@tomfgoodwin I fast forward TV ads, haven't read print in years, use select websites instead. I haven't listened to radio in years, why when you can stream music you like. The above is the case for almost everyone I know...

@tomfgoodwin I don’t know about that. I’m typing this to you on a handheld mobile device and will go home tonight and watch Netflix or VOD which is “tv” but not as, say MMM understands it. Agree that it’s not about 1 channel but many

@tomfgoodwin Isn’t this what happens everywhere. More information than ever before about everything and yet opinion seems to trump fact more than ever. Data without authority to curate and interpret it is not credible. Who’s the authority now?
@NoahMallin Not that much. Not for most people.
@tomfgoodwin Yes BUT - people's behavior has changed - often in ways that are hard to quantify with traditional data sources.

@tomfgoodwin Is the doctor from Beverly Hills or Sedona? Because then I could see that.

But of course I get your point, for those in audience wondering.

Imagine a Doctor saying 
"Look I know that we know how MRI scanners work & that they do work & they still work, but they've been around my whole career. I went to a conference about this new type of healing crystals, everyone is trying it so let's be one of the first to try that"
